characters: EXT ROCKY PATH HIGH ABOVE HOUSE
LITTLE LOCKED DOOR THAT IS BREATHING WITH ANTICIPATION
-- ROLLS HERSELF AWAKE IN HER OWN BED. FAST PULL BACK
STARTS TO CATCH UP TO HER
SHINY BLACK BUTTONS HIT THE FLOOR
COMING UP BEHIND HER VERY FAST
EXT STUDY DOOR TO BACK PORCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline races down past an OLD TRACTOR and into an ORCHARD. WIND begins to blow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEW ANGLE as we move beside Coraline through the old apple trees, where she nearly trips on the tongue of a harvest cart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOWN ANGLE ON on Coraline as she BACKS INTO a circle of TOADSTOOLS in front of a STUMP. BREATHING HARD, she looks out for her pursuer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEW ANGLE. The black cat shoots past Coraline in the tall grass. She can't see him but she knows something is there. Already behind her now, the cat LEAPS onto the stump with a loud, warning MEROWWW!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STARTLED, Coraline YELLS and whips around. She's both angry and relieved when she sees it's just some cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You scared me to death, you mangy thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cat GLARES at her with BLUE OPAL EYES, makes a low growl as she stands. She exhales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just looking for an old well. Know it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cat BLINKS EYES slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not talking, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind picks up. She grasps the forks of her stick, closes her eyes, and, tracing a figure eight above her,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magic dowser, magic dowser: show... me... the well!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON CORALINE FROM HIGH BLUFF. The SPY moves into frame, astride some kind of MOTOR-BIKE. He presses a button on the handlebars and BLASTS a loud AIR HORN. STARTLED, Coraline SPINS around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UP ANGLE ON SPY. As LIGHTNING FLASHES and THUNDER ROLLS, Coraline sees him for the first time. With his turret- lensed SKULL MASK and SKELETON GLOVES and black FIREMAN'S COAT flapping in the wind, he looks like a PSYCHO KILLER!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (freaked out) AHHHHH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He REVS his motor, pops a wheelie, then SWOOPS DOWN the bluff towards her. She HOLLERS IN FEAR, then tries to WHACK HIM with her forked stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GET AWAY FROM ME--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He SNATCHES it from her as he passes, KNOCKING HER to the ground. He SIDE-SKIDS his bike, hops off and JUMPS UP onto the stump. Looking TEN FEET TALL from the ground, THUNDER AND LIGHTNING at a peak, the Spy turns his THREE- EYED TURRET LENS and studies her like a predatory alien.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then, the thunder and lightning just FADE OUT and this psycho-killer, three-eyed spy pulls off his mask and Coraline GASPS -- he's just a short kid in a costume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoulders hunched, neck bent, the Spy - real name WYBIE LOVAT - aged 12 - examines Coraline's forked stick, aims it around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoo! Let me guess, you're from Texas or Utah; someplace dried out and barren, right? I heard about water-witching before but it doesn't make sense; I mean, it's just an ordinary branch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline, SNATCHES it from his GLOVED HANDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IT'S A DOWSING ROD!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline smacks Wybie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I DON'T LIKE BEING STALKED, not by PSYCHO-NERDS OR THEIR CATS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crouches, nervous, to scratch the cat behind his ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not really my cat; he's kinda feral В­ you know, wild? Of course, I do feed him every night and sometimes he'll come in my window `n bring me little dead things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat PURRS like a diesel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm from Pontiac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHIGAN? And if I'm a "water witch", THEN-- (points stick, stomps foot) --where's the secret WELL?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stomp too hard and you'll fall in it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline reacts, hops out of the springy circle. The boy scrapes at the ground, revealing a CIRCULAR COVERING made of WOODEN PLANKS. He wedges a fallen branch under one side, and, using a rock for the fulcrum, pries up the covering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? Supposed to be so deep if you fell to the bottom and looked up, you'd see a sky full of stars in the middle of the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her frown RELAXES and the black cat tilts his head, noticing her change in tone. He steps off the branch, and the well cover thumps in place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprised she let you move in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerks his head toward the pink house in distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... my Gramma. She owns the "Pink Palace" (indicates house in distance) Won't rent to people with kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly worried) Uh... I'm not supposed to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Changing the subject, he lifts a gloved hand to shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Wybie, Wybie Lovat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wybie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Short for Wyborne. Not my idea, of course. What'd you get saddled with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't saddled with anything. It's Coraline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline. Coraline Jones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused, not hearing it) Hmmm... It's not real scientific, but I heard an ordinary name, like Caroline --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her face goes as DARK as the rain clouds above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- can lead people to have ordinary expectations about a person--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling from afar) Wyborne!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I heard someone calling you, Wyborne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? I didn't hear anything--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I definitely heard someone, Why-were- you-born.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A distant dinner bell clangs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wyborne!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath, nervous) Grandma!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds up his hands in surrender, nodding with eyes closed, forcing some laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heh. Well, great to meet a Michigan water witch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up his bike, wheels it around, then holds up his gloved hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'd wear gloves next time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to her dowsing rod, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Cause that dowsing rod of yours? Uh, it's poison oak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ehh!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline drops the stick as he zooms away and wipes her hands on her clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat merows at her, shaking his head with a pitying look, then trots away after Wybie. She STICKS OUT HER TONGUE at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks down at the COVERING to the well. Coraline finds a PEBBLE and drops it through A SMALL KNOT-HOLE. Ear at the knot-hole, she counts until there's a watery "plop" far below. FAT RAINDROPS start to fall around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's POURING out. Coraline looks out a window at the DEAD LOOKING GARDEN, and places PACKETS OF SEEDS - pumpkins, squash, snap dragons, bleeding hearts - on the sill. She's developed a REDDISH RASH - poison oak - on one hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The main floor kitchen, like most   things in the Pink Palace, is barely maintained, and   looks worn and faded. Coraline's MOTHER, MEL JONES, 40,   bangs away at her laptop on the table, MOVING BOXES   stacked nearby. She's plain-looking and tired and wears   a NECK-BRACE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I almost fell down a well yesterday, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not listening) Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continues typing) That's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline scratches the rash on her hand, changes subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm. So can I go out? I think it's perfect weather for gardening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Coraline. Rain makes mud. Mud makes a mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Mom, I want stuff growing when my friends come to visit. Isn't that why we moved here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that. But then we had the accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't my fault you hit that truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never said it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe it -- you and Dad get paid to write about plants and you hate dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mel stops typing, loses her patience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline, I don't have time for you right now. And you still have unpacking to do. Lots of unpacking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds exciting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mel remembers something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mel (CONT'D) Oh - some kid left this on the front porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline walks over and is handed a NEWSPAPER-WRAPPED PACKAGE. Attached note reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Jonesy, look what I found in Gramma's trunk. Look familiar? Wybie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rips open the package and finds the BUTTON-EYED, BLUE HAIRED, YELLOW RAINCOAT-WEARING DOLL from the head credits - it's a litte Coraline!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself) Huh... a little me? That's weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crumples the note, both annoyed and charmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's his name, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wybie. And I'm way too old for dolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Coraline takes it with her and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE Jones, 40, goose-necked and gangly with thinning dark hair, HUNT-AND-PECKS at his ancient computer, surrounded by boxes of GARDENING MAGAZINES and empty coffee cups. Coraline, with doll, opens the SQUEAKY DOOR. He doesn't turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Dad, how's the writing going?... Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ignores her reflection in his computer screen as he types away, green letters on black. She CLEARS HER THROAT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Coraline... (notices doll's reflection) And... Coraline doll?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'you know where the garden tools are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hears rain outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pouring out there, isn't it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Humph, it's just raining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd the boss say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Don't even think about going out, Coraline Jones."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you won't need the tools.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline GROANS, stamps her feet. Charlie just taps harder on the keys. Pouting, she makes the door squeak, opening and shutting it till he can't take any more. He spins around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhhh, you know, this house is a hundred and fifty years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So explore it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs a pen and pad, holds it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go out and ... count all the doors and windows and write that down. List everything blue!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just let me work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rolls her eyes, takes paper and pen and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline, with doll, jumps on BUMP in carpet that moves with each jump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wipes off the misted glass so she and the doll can see out, then writes in her pad: 7 leaky windows. A drop of water lands on the pad, smearing the ink. She adds really between 7 and leaky windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline thumps the carpet bump again and pounds up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FRAMED PHOTO sits in the foreground on a beside table. It shows a younger, happier Coraline with her parents by the BEAR FOUNTAIN at the Detroit Zoo. RACK FOCUS to bedroom door as it swings into the room, with Coraline hanging on it. She drops to the ground and, doll and pad in hand, decides to check out the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she pulls aside the mildewed shower curtain she finds a hundred skittering SILVERFISH BUGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ewww!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disgusted, she jumps into the tub and smashes as many as she can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns on the faucet to wash her hands, only to get soaked with rusty water from the shower head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes out her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline pounds down the stairs, spots the carpet bump again in the hallway and jumps on it. A closet door opens, a light on inside, and she goes to investigate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE OVER water heater on Coraline. She jots down one rusty water heater in her pad. As she leaves, she flicks off the light switch, not noticing a note taped beside it that says: Do not turn off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights flicker and then Charlie's computer dies. He hollers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no, no; GAAAA--!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --AAAAAAA!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline reacts with guilty alarm, runs back to the closet and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- spots the Do not turn off note. She flips the light switch back on and gets out of there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is faded and cold with bare windows looking out on rain and gray. The floor is strewn with moving boxes, a few pieces of furniture, Charlie's old Nordic Track. A few garden tools lean against one wall; a cardboard mattress box leans against a corner wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline enters, counting windows and doors to note in her pad. She sets the doll on a low table beside an open moving box and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The box is filled with her mom's collection of SNOWGLOBES. She takes out her favorite - the BEAR FOUNTAIN AT THE DETROIT ZOO - and shakes it. She studies the globe and sighs with homesickness. She sets it carefully on the FIREPLACE MANTEL, then unwraps the rest of the snowglobes and places them beside it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the mantel hangs a PAINTING of a CRYING BOY IN BLUE a scoop of ice cream melting on his shirt, his hand holding an EMPTY CONE. Coraline takes up pad and pen and adds to her list, muttering aloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One boring blue boy in a painfully boring painting ... four incredibly boring windows ... and no... more... doors...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to grab the doll off the table by the snow globe box. It's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, little me, where are you hiding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scanning the room, she spots the doll LOOKING OUT FROM BEHIND THE MATTRESS BOX leaned against the corner wall. Perplexed, she walks over and kneels down to grab the doll when she notices SOMETHING ON THE WALL behind the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shoves the box aside, and discovers the outline of a SMALL DOOR that's been wallpapered over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intensely curious, she calls to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Mom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, typing away, ignores her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where does this door go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really, really busy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline tries to open it but there's no handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleeeeeeeeease!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mel gets up, really annoyed. Big sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhhh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks over to Coraline, looks at the outline of the door in the ratty old wallpaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you stop pestering me if I do this for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline nods her head quickly, PANTING like a dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She heads back to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mel pulls open a drawer, pushes a bunch of loose brass and nickel keys aside to find a small, sharp black key. Holds it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mel cuts the wallpaper around the door and sticks the key in the lock. Coraline looks on, giddy with anticipation, the doll at her side. Mel turns the key, unlocks the door, and pulls it open to reveal ... an UNBROKEN BRICK WALL. Coraline is totally disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bricks? I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline scratches her wrist rash with annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They must have closed this off when they divided up the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mel gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding? And why is the door so small?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mel leaving room, turns back, and loses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We made a deal. ZIP IT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits. Coraline makes annoyed sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't lock it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AaaaaH!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline pushes the little door shut, her head lowered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE ANGLE ON HOUSE. Pouring rain. We hear Charlie singing a song about Coraline, badly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my twitchy witchy girl,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE, using OVEN MITT to protect his hand, takes a BURNED-UP CASSEROLE DISH from the oven while mom closes up her LAPTOP. Coraline sits at the table with her doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you are so nice, I give you bowls of porridge And I give you bowls of ice --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE sets the dish on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (really bad note) -- cream!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline pushes it away, disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you ever cook, Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline, we've been through this before: your Dad cooks, I clean, and you stay out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline HUFFS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear I'll go food shopping soon as we finish the catalog. (indicates Coraline's plate) Try some of the chard, you need a vegetable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks more like slime to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's slime or bedtime fusspot -- now what's it going to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline looks to her doll, cradles its head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think they're trying to poison me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes the doll's head nod "yes." Coraline rolls her eyes, looks up to the heavens and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- falls back, washed and dressed for bed, on her pillow. Still raining out. Coraline puts the doll on the chair beside her, then scratches at her wrist. ORIGAMI DRAGONFLIES are strung between the tall, thin bed posts; the TURTLE SHELL she found in the garden sits up on a box, her NIGHT LAMP that projects stars and moons is warming up on the bedside table. Despite her efforts at decorating, Coraline's new bedroom feels small and cold, cracked and faded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline reaches for a framed PHOTO that rests on a toy PRAYING MANTIS by her night lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's her TWO BEST FRIENDS from home, posing in the snow by her old school's marquee, its letters rearranged to spell "CORALINE, GOOD BYE!" She touches her friends' faces with her fingertips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget about me, guys. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts back the photo, hits the light switch over her bed and, looking over at the doll, sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-night...little me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her breathing slows and, with the doll WATCHING HER, she starts to fall asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --SURREAL MIST SWIRLS out her window. MOONS AND STARS SLOWLY MOVE across the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOMETHING in the room goes t-t-t-t-t-t. Coraline sits up, awake. SOMETHING CHITTERS under her bed. She leans over her bedside, head first, peering underneath when a ghost- pale KANGAROO MOUSE JUMPS OUT and bounds out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives chase, down the upper hall, down the stairs, snaps on the lower hall light, sees it hop into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline enters. The mouse edges out from beneath the sofa, then hops frantically toward the SMALL DOOR behind the wallpaper! Coraline runs and dives, but the door is open a crack, and the mouse escapes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline grabs the door's edge and pulls it open. Instead of a brick wall, there is a DARK, EXPANDING TUNNEL, with the hopping mouse heading towards a bluish light at the far end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She catches her breath, pulls the door wider and CRAWLS THROUGH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline MOVES FORWARD, towards the light ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline steps out through the same little door, into what looks like the EXACT SAME LIVING ROOM she just left, only something is different -- it feels deeper, more dimensional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks around, notices the painting over the fireplace: the crying blue boy is now SMILING, his shirt clean and his ice cream back on his cone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From across the hall, warm light comes from the kitchen and the smell of delicious food wafts towards her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MMMMM, something smells good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline enters to see her mother cooking at the stove, wearing an apron and ROOSTER-HEAD OVEN MITTS. The light and colors are much warmer and the details more perfect in this kitchen. Other Mother is facing away from Coraline as she works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom?! What are you doing here in the middle of the night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her mother turns from the stove to greet her and Coraline is DUMBSTRUCK: she's got BUTTONS FOR EYES! She beams with happiness at Coraline's arrival.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just in time for supper, dear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother doesn't have b-b-buh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline points to her own eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B-b-b-buttons? Do you like them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She taps one with her nail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your Other Mother, silly. Now go tell your Other Father that supper's ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the oven door and the intoxicating perfume of great cooking fills the air. Coraline breathes it in, suddenly VERY HUNGRY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, go on. He's in his study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline goes down the hall and opens the study door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sees the back of a man like her father, only with more hair. Instead of tapping away at his computer, though, he's picking notes on a BABY GRAND PIANO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns around. He, too, has SHINY BUTTON EYES. He seems happier and a little more handsome than real Dad, and wears an IRIDESCENT ROBE over POLKA DOT PAJAMAS, with ORANGE MONKEY SLIPPERS on his feet. He smiles broadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Coraline. Want to hear my new song?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father can't play piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need to ... this piano plays ME!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. SEUSS GLOVES В­ connected with rods and pulleys В­ PO OUT of the piano's front and ONTO HIS HANDS. His hands RAISE UP В­ then DROP DOWN to play pounding STRIDE PIANO as Other Father SINGS out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Making up a song about Coraline. She's a peach, she's a doll, she's a pal of mine. She's as cute as a button in the eyes of everyone who ever laid their eyes on Cor- a-line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline is amazed as his hands fly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she comes around exploring Mom and I will never ever make it boring our eyes will be on Coraline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anxious, she taps his shoulder to stop him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, uh В­ sorry В­ but she said to tell you the food's ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmmm! Who's starving? Raise your hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sticks his hand up, still in a glove, and his other gloved hand slaps his face. She LAUGHS, then covers her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other Mother sets down a HUGE, ROASTED CHICKEN near Coraline on a table spread with CANDLES, fine CHINA and SILVER and a PINEAPPLE CENTERPIECE. FIGURE EIGHT MODEL TRAIN TRACKS circle twin LAZY SUSANS covered in dishes of POTATOES, SWEET PEAS, ROLLS, and CORN. The Other Father seals this Norman Rockwell moment by making PRAYER HANDS and a solemn face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We give our thanks and ask to bless, Our Mother's golden chicken breast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs with glee then a STARTING BELL rings and it's time to eat. Other Father really digs in while Coraline tries some chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm, this chicken is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hungry, aren't you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding, mouth full) D'you have any gravy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, here comes the gravy train! Choo- choo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other Mother GIGGLES as a MODEL TRAIN circles round the track, pulling a GRAVY BOAT CAR and blowing its whistle. The train goes in one side of the centerpiece and comes out the other, slowing till the gravy boat lines up with Coraline's plate, where it POURS GRAVY on her potatoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another roll, sweet peas? Corn on the cob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other Mother looks on approvingly, not touching any food herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mouth full) I'm real thirsty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course! Any requests?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful CHANDELIER DRINK DISPENSER descends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mango milk shake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dispenser SPINS, stops and fills her glass while Other Mother presents dessert: a cake with candles that POP UP and LIGHT THEMSELVES while the words "WELCOME HOME!" write themselves in icing. Coraline is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her Other Parents squeeze each other's hands warmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been waiting for you, Coraline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. Wasn't the same here without you, kiddo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline remains a little unsure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know I had an Other Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you do. Everyone does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles at Coraline, her button eyes gleaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh, and soon as you're through eating, I thought we'd play a game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She taps her fingers a little too excitedly on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean like, hide and seek?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect! Hide and seek in the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What rain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUNDER, LIGHTNING, then RAIN appears outside the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh, what about the mud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We love mud here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other Mother rises, walks towards Coraline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mud facials, mud baths, mud pies -- it's great for poison oak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The takes Coraline's rashy hand, but Coraline pulls it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you know I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline adjusts her tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, I'd love to play, but ... I better get home to my other mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm your other mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean my other other mother. Mom number one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I should get to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, sweetheart, it's all made up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes head) But ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other Father steps in beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come along, sleepyhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lead her from the table towards the stairs to her bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In this world, Coraline's bedroom is a dream come true: it is filled with rich color and light; there's a fire in the fireplace, a sheer, lacy canopy over her now beautiful bed. And her favorite toys are alive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her ORIGAMI DRAGONFLIES FLUTTER towards her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Coraline, hello, hello!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her BLUE SQUID greets her with a WAVE of its tentacle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's shakin', baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TURTLE SHELL she'd found CIRCLES HER FEET on clothes pin legs, making PANTING SOUNDS. She laughs, then hears two voices from beside her bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, how zit goin', yuper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your swampers and tuke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She jumps onto the bed, grabs the photo of her best friends from home, now ALIVE IN THE PHOTO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kripes a-mighty, how are my best trolls? I can't wait till summer. You're both comin', right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're already here, Coraline --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- gone to Or-e-gine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline grins hugely, then, exhausted, she yawns, stretching out her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Other Mother, in the bedside chair, takes her hand and applies some SOOTHING BLACK MUD to Coraline's poison oak rash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the mud...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Other Mother gently tucks her in then she and the Other Father smile at Coraline as she drifts off to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OTHER MOTHER                  OTHER FATHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you soon ...              See you soon ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline awakens. She looks around expecting bright colors, a magic dragonfly. But it's just her NORMAL ROOM: moving boxes; cracks in the ceiling -- nothing's changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She notices the BUTTON-EYED DOLL on the chair where she left it, where the Other Mother was sitting. She picks it up, absentmindedly goes to scratch her wrist. She stops, noticing that the rash on her wrist IS GONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gone, my poison oak, it's gone!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline goes to the little door, still ajar. She peeks behind and finds the WALL OF SOLID BRICKS. Yes, it was only a dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head and pushes the door shut. The kettle blows from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breakfast. Mel and Charlie finish their "Go Lean Breakfast Twigs" and mugs of instant coffee. Preoccupied with their work, they half-listen as Coraline recounts her dream, her breakfast untouched. FOG lies outside the windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was incredibly real, Mom! Only you weren't really you; you were my other mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buttons for eyes, huh? (indicates untouched food) Coraline, you only dreamed you ate all that chicken. Take your multi-vitamin, at least.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were in the dream too, Dad. You had wild-looking pajamas and orange monkey slippers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pretend offense) Orange? My monkey slippers are blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands, put his dishes in the sink. Whispers over his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pssst. Can you get me some of that magic mud you were talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She points to her rash-free wrists. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I have a terrible case of writer's rash. On my---.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mel CLEARS HER THROAT, interrupting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the real Charlie Jones wants his pages edited, he'd better wrap them up ASAP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crisply salutes her, turns on his heel, and marches out the door. Mel gets up to clear the table with Coraline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline, why don't you go visit downstairs? I bet those "actresses" would love to hear your dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Spink and Forcible? But you said they're dingbats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline sighs, gets up to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's drizzling and a WHITE FOG has lowered over the house and grounds. Coraline В­ yellow rain poncho, garden SHEAR in hand В­ opens the front door. Stepping out onto the porch, she TRIPS on a big bundle of mail. Annoyed, she picks it up, starts leafing through the envelopes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bo-bin-sky...Bo-bin-sky....Bo-bin-sky...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smells something bad, sniffs the envelopes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohh, Poo-eeeee!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes down the front steps and finds a sign that reads "Bobinsky there" with an arrow that points up long, winding outside stairs. With an "oh well" shrug, she goes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the top, she knocks on the door, a little anxious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: H-hello?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knocks again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think our mail got mixed up.    Should I leave it outside or...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door swings open. Curious, Coraline peeks inside: it's dark and cramped with something boiling on the stove and a caged chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly a HUGE BLUE MAN swings down behind her and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SEE-KRET...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She whips around to find MR. Bobinsky - upside down, reaching right at her face! She ducks and he reaches past her to his actual target - his door knob - and pulls it shut. The Russian giant, dressed in a sleeveless T-shirt and shorts, pulls a RAW BEET from his pants. He's not happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Famous Jumping Mouse Circus not ready, little girl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Circus?... Oh, uh, I brought this for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds out his mail. Bobinsky takes it, smelling the stinky envelopes deeply. Nods approvingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm... Noviseer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New "cheese" samples.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swings down like a spider monkey and stands beside her on the balcony. Coraline backs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very clever, using this "mix up" to sneak my home and peek at meeshkas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meeshkas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mice!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry. I'm Coraline Jones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I am the Amazing Bobinsky! But you can call me Mr. B, because amazing I already know that I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smells his mail again, makes pleased sound, then seems to fall off the side of the third story porch! Coraline rushes over, looks down. He cartwheels in from the porch railing behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha! You see, Caroline, the problem is my new songs go oompah oompah. But the jumping mice play only toodle toot, like that. Is nice, but not so much amazing? So now-- (indicates smelly mail) --I switch to stronger cheese, and soon В­ VATCH OUT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens his door, crouches low and turns. He hands her a beet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, have beet. Make you strong. (salutes her ) Daas vee DAAN ya, Caroline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He scuttles inside and slams the door shut. Coraline mutters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cor-a-line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking at the beet, she makes a disgusted sound and tosses it away, then heads down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she gets to the bottom, she starts towards the back, gardening shears out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself) Oompah oompah, toodle toot, toodle toot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EHHH! CAROLINE: PA-DAZH-DI'-- WAIT!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobinsky LEAPS all the way to the ground, landing beside her, out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mice...asked me to give you message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The...jumping mice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. B nods gravely. He leans down, so close his moustache touches her ear, and whispers, his voice DEAD-SERIOUS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are saying: do not go through leetle door. Do you know such a thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline is startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one behind the wall paper? But... it's all bricked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man shrugs, straightens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bah. So sorry, is nothing. Sometimes the mice are leetle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to his head and rotates his finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...mixed up, hmmm? They even get your name wrong, you know. They call you Coraline instead of Caroline, not Caroline at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts back up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I work them too hard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline stares after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEARS IN HAND, Coraline approaches the family VW, where one PINK SUITCASE remains tied to the roof. She snips it free and takes out her special HAT, a black Japanese schoolboy's cap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline climbs down the steps to the basement flat. At the door, she tries the comedy/tragedy door knocker and waits. Nothing. She glances down at the doormat - it reads "No whistling in the house."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She peers through the door glass. A YAPPING DOG suddenly LEAPS UP inside, startling her, and a moment after, MISS SPINK В­ wearing some sort of house robe В­ opens the doo and three SCOTTIE DOGS В­ HAMISH, JOCK, AND ANGUS В­ shoo out and surround Coraline. Spink tries to quiet them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh cease your infernal yapping! (to Coraline, sweetly) How nice to see you, Caroline. Would you like to come in? We're playing cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still Coraline, Miss Spink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over shoulder) Miriam, put the kettle on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. MISSES SPINK & FORCIBLE'S FLAT - SAME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Spink leads Coraline into the living area, as MISS FORCIBLE, taller and sporting a platinum wig and a very large bosom, prepares tea in the kitchen to the side. The dogs race ahead and jump onto the sofa. Coraline scans the walls to see framed POSTERS from the "Shakespeare" the ladies used to perform like King Leer and Julius Seize Her. Miss Forcible peers out her, half-blind without her glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April, I think you're being followed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the new neighbor, Miriam - Caroline? She'll be having the Oolong tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no. I'm sure she'd prefer Jasmine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Oolong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Jasmine it is, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forcible grabs a handful of tea, puts it in the pot and pours boiling water in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, boys!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dogs leap off the sofa and, as Coraline takes their place, she looks to the side and sees a towering bookcase filled with STUFFED SCOTTY DOGS IN KNITTED SWEATERS WITH ANGEL WINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are those dogs .... real?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our sweet, departed angels. Couldn't bear to part with them ... so we had them stuffed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, there's Hamish the third, the fourth, the eighth, the ninth. Angus the second, the fifth, the..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Forcible arrives with a tea tray and urges Coraline to take a candy as Spink goes on and on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh go on, have one В­ it's hand-pulled taffy from Brighton В­ best in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline reaches for a pink and green one. But the taffy is so old and sticky, her fingers get stuck. Then her other hand gets stuck, trying to get the first hand out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...seventh, the third, the ninth, yes, the fourthI'm right; and Jock Junior, Jock senior, Jock the third, the fourth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline, using her feet, finally un-sticks the candy bowl which FLIES UP and sticks to the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...oh, and that's Jock's 2nd cousin, twice removed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to Coraline, about to sip her tea. Spink indicates cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll read them, if you like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, your tea leaves, dear. They'll tell me your future. Drink up then, go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline gulps down the bitter brew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not all of it, not all of it. That's right, now hand it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline passes her the cup. Spink puts a saucer on top and swirls it three times, removes the saucer and peers in at the abstract leaf pattern. She purses her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... Caroline, Caroline, Caroline; you are in terrible danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Forcible snorts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, give me that cup, April, your eyes are going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My eyes! You're blind as a bat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spink passes the cup to Forcible, who adjusts thick glasses and peers closely into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, now, ummm... not to worry, child, it's good news: there's a tall, handsome beast in your future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miriam, oh really, you're holding it wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spink forcibly rotates the cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? Danger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline wants more information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ladies, heads side by side, gaze into the cup. We see a SPIKY CLAW formed from the leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see a very peculiar hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forcible rotates the cup back again. Upside down, the claw hand looks like a GIRAFFE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see a giraffe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giraffes don't just fall from the sky, Miriam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stuck candy dish suddenly CRASHES to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, lord!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline asks in a practical voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what should I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never wear green in your dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acquire a very tall step ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And be very, very careful. Now, was there something you came to tell us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline thinks it over, then shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I guess not. Thanks for the tea, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up and leaves, the dogs immediately return to their sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toodle-oo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheery-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ladies resume their card game with Miss Spink turning to the dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any nice Queens for mummy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline climbs the stairs up to ground level, intrigued by her fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself) Danger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind her, a PERISCOPE RISES from the WAIST-DEEP FOG. Coraline just catches it in her peripheral view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She frowns but doesn't let on she's aware of it. She walks ahead nonchalantly, the periscope following her, then suddenly turns and GRABS it, PULLING UP WYBIE, then PUNCHES him in the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Owwwwwwww!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great, the village stalker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow. I - I wasn't stalking you. We're hunting banana slugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wybie takes some SALAD TONGS from a tool belt, snaps them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'ya mean, "we?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a soft meowing from under his coat. He opens it up and the BLACK CAT EMERGES and climbs onto his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha! Your cat's not wild, he's a wuss- puss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cat glares at her angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? He hates to get his feet wet. Geez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wuss-puss...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tired of her company, the cat jumps off Wybie, onto a tree and up onto the roof of the house. Coraline softens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... that doll. Did you make it look like me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wybie, scanning under the ground fog for slugs, sticks his head up for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no; I found it that way. It's older than Gramma -- old as this house prob'ly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline is highly skeptical. Wybie returns to his hunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points to self) C'mom - blue hair, my swampers and raincoat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wybie stands excitedly and presents a HUGE YELLOW-GREEN SLUG to Coraline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dang, check out Slugzilla!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just like them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks from the slug to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant my parents; they don't listen to me either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wybie nods, not listening again, takes his camera --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh... You mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- hands it to her. She acts put-out, but frames a shot. He signals he's ready and she fires off one auto-flash shot after another as he strikes silly poses making SOUND EFFECTS: horrified of the slug one moment; ready to eat it the next; pretending it's something from his nose in another. She can't help but GIGGLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ew!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finished, Wybie tosses the slug back into the fog, and takes the camera back. He lowers his head, thoughtful, then glances up past Coraline at the house. He SIGHS and speaks in a SAD TONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I've never been inside the Pink Palace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandma would kill me. Thinks it's dangerous or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dangerous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... she had a twin sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they were kids, Grandma's sister disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says she was stolen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stolen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE from roof, over CAT'S SHOULDER as dialog continues. Cat senses something and turns -- it's Coraline's DOLL AT THE WINDOW, looking like it's spying on things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhhh, I-I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK TO KIDS. Wybie, astride his electric bike now, WHISTLES and the black cat jumps down from the roof, onto his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she just ran away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear Wybie's agitated grandmother call out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wyborne!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wybie turns away: he's said too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to pull away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's gone. PUSH IN on her pensive face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU ON DOLL FACE, back in   the chair by the bed. Coraline takes some yellow cheese   from her pocket and puts it by the door: mice bait. She   lies down and her breathing slows, the doll watching   her with a nearly IMPERCEPTIBL SMILE on its face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline sleeping, lighting suggests another dream. SOME THINGS go t-t-t-t-t-t. Coraline sits up, looks to her door, and spots a COUPLE OF KANGAROO MICE stealing the last bit of cheese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives chase after the mice, hopping down the stairs with the cheese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline follows the kangaroo mice directly to the little door, opened a crack, where they disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls it open. Bricks are gone; tunnel revealed. She doesn't hesitate this time to crawl through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline enters Other Kitchen to find Other Mother preparing a delicious breakfast. She looks PRETTIER tonight; her black hair shining, lips REDDER. She stops HUMMING A LULLABY to greet Coraline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome back, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is grating YELLOW CHEESE into scrambled eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So thoughtful of you to send this nice cheddar, Coraline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheddar?... Oh, the mice bait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you go fetch your father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beams at Coraline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet he's hungry as a pumpkin by now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean my Other Father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your better father, dear.   He's out in the garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But my parents don't have time to garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other Mother SHUSHES her and pops a strawberry in her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmmmm!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline shrugs okay, starts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking out, she sees the broken-down garden from the real world, still grey and lifeless in the dim light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline opens the gate to the garden. A large CRESCENT MOON RISES, and THINGS START TO GROW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two dead shrubs start to RISE, then BLOSSOM, then the blossoms themselves are LIT UP by some GOLD AND AMBER HUMMINGBIRDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hummingbirds circle around Coraline, light her DRAGONFLY BARRETTE, then continue on, LIGHTING UP PITCHER PLANTS that have grown up in a nearby flower bed. A beautiful FROG POKES OUT of one blossom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The birds lead Coraline up steps past a stone wall where BLEEDING HEART GROW, AND GLOW, AND BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She spots the Other Father, riding a PRAYING MANTIS TRACTOR on the hillside, planting SEEDS that instantly grow into FLOWERING PLANTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love your garden!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves back, calling:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our garden, Coraline!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gang of SNAP DRAGONS goes at her, TICKLING Coraline till she falls down. Her squeals of delight grow into HYSTERICAL LAUGHTER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh ah, stop! Stop tickling, ah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Other Father hears this and looks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oops, daughter in distress!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He guns the tractor full-speed over a little bridge, grabbing a GOURD TRUMPET from a vine and blowing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK-O-LANTERNS surface in the pond below and spout STREAMS OF WATER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arriving beside Coraline, he waggles his finger at the naughty snapdragons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tickle no more, you dragon snappers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he deftly cuts a bouquet of them and presents it to Coraline. She nods thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she says it's time for dinner ... breakfast ... food?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hop on, kiddo, I want to show you something!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does. The Other Father grabs the GEARSHIFT KNOB, pulls it, and the mechanical mantis SPROUTS WINGS. They RISE in the air. Looking down, she sees that the garden is a PORTRAIT OF CORALINE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you did this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother said you'd like it! Boy she knows you like the back of her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls a lever and they ZOOM out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline doesn't hold back this time. She stacks sausages on eggs on top of waffles, rolls it up and stuffs it in her mouth. The Other Mother FEEDS BITS OF SAUSAGE to the HUNGRY SNAPDRAGONS bouquet now in a vase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm...so good!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love dinner, breakfast food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline, Mr. Bobinsky has invited you to come see the Jumping Mice perform after dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. That know-it-all Wybie said it was all in Mr. B's head, I knew he was wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, everything's right in this world, Kiddo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline hurries to shovel in the rest of her meal, while her Other Parents smile at one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father and I will clean up while you and your friend head upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a KNOCK at the door. Other Mother opens it to reveal the OTHER WYBIE. He's cleaner, with better posture, and cute button eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great... another Wybie. Hello, Why-were- you-born.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy nods, button eyes shining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just makes a shy smile, doesn't answer. She's confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you'd like him more, if he spoke a little less. (shrugs, smiling) So I fixed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he can't talk at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks Other Wybie over appreciatively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm, I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now run along, you two, and have fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline heads out the door with the mute boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Other House В­ lit by amber spotlights looks MAGICAL with ornate GINGERBREAD TRIM; glowing TOPIARY in the yard. The kids come out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're awful cheerful, considering you can't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other Wybie nods in agreement. Coraline and he start up the stairs to Bobinsky's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh...It didn't hurt, did it, when she...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She points to her mouth. There's an awkward moment and then he points past her, excitedly: a SMALL BLIMP is flying towards Bobinsky's door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They run up the stairs and watch it slip through an opening above his door. Coraline knocks and the door suddenly SPINS, THROWING THEM INSIDE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They somersault to a stop and sit up. Down two rows of SMALL CANNONS that face each, an amazing MINIATURE CIRCUS has been set up, with a FERRIS WHEEL beside it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa... cool!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline goes right to the Ferris wheel where a MECHANICAL CHICKEN eats dried corn on the cob, fires up its belly, then POOPS OUT POPCORN into paper bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other Wybie stomps a firing button and COTTON CANDY shoots out of a cannon. He catches the cone, then starts firing off all the cannons. Coraline looks back to find him covered in the cotton candy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spotlights come on in the big top, the entrance opens, and a big voice is heard over loudspeakers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady and gentleman! For to tickle your eyes and ears and making hearts to thump, I В­ Sergei Alexander Bobinsky В­ am introducing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They race to the entrance, stoop down to crawl inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... my as-tound-ishing, stu-pen-dulous and AH-MAZING Jumping Mouse Circus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit between miniature grandstands and watch as the little BLIMP, bathed in spotlights, enters through a flap. It circles around, rising to the top of the tent, then NOSE-DIVES towards the ground! It CRASHES in the center of the circus ring, and OPENS LIKE A FLOWER from which 50 JUMPING MICE spring up like Chinese acrobats to spell out C O R A L I N E.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jumping mice leap to the ground in formation, BRANDISH TINY INSTRUMENTS, and DRUMMERS START POUNDING. The DRUM MAJOR MOUSE parachutes down and whips out a BATON. On his signal, the group launch into a WILD RUSSIAN CIRCUS MARCH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline, grinning, turns to the Other Wybie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's wonderful, Wybie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy smiles and nods to the beat of the bass drums as the hopping band marches in and out of ever changing formations - PINWHEELS, X's, CIRCLES WITHIN CIRCLES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hoppers begin to SPIRAL to the center of the circus ring when the floor RISES UP from its center to form a six-foot Tower of Babel, the mice HOPPING TO THE TOP. The DRUM MAJOR balances on the tippy-top on a COLORFUL CIRCUS BALL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He RUNS the ball DOWN AND AROUND the spiral as the MICE HOP OFF, and when he hits the ground, the TOWER DROPS AWAY to reveal the OTHER MISTER BOBINSKY! He CRACKS A WHIP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline and Other Wybie STAND and CLAP. Other Bobinsky В in a RINGMASTER'S OUTFIT with a full length cape В­ bows graciously, doffing his tall black hat. His moustache is waxed, his eyes black buttons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah! Whooo-oooh! That was great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very very thank you, lady and gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On cue, the entire jumping mice band DISAPPEARS INTO OTHER MR. B'S SLEEVES while the drum major SWINGS UP from the man's moustache and onto his head, where he's quickly hidden by the tall black hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We loved it, Mr. B. It was ... so ... so--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AHHHHHH---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A-mazing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are very velcome anytime you like, you and also your good friend there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She happily turns to Other Wybie, beaming with joy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dosvedanya, Coraline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobinsky takes her hand to kiss it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other Mother kisses SLEEPING CORALINE'S forehead, sits back in the bedside chair. Other Father, close by, pulls a cotton candy cone off Other Wybie and munches it. Coraline's Other Parents smile warmly, knowing something secret that makes them glad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EARLY MORNING. Coraline once again wakes in own bed in the real world, the little doll В­ left on the chair В­ n clutched against her chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ughhh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her gaze moves from the doll to where she left the cheese by the door. It's GONE. This is much too confusing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline tries the small door in the corner wall. It's locked. What the heck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --SQUEALING brakes, as the Jones' JEEP pulls up in front of "Northwest Garden" headquarters. TOWNSFOLK in SHAKESPEAREAN COSTUMES stand about, advertising a local festival. Coraline is sharing her latest dream:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... there were garden squash like balloon animals AND snap dragons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON FAMILY: Coraline continues from back seat as her father and mother review their work pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, and upstairs I saw a real mouse circus, not pretend like the crazy man's in our house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her parents, preoccupied, ignore her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you won't come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicates neck brace) Don't fret, Charlie, they'll love the new catalog. At least, they'll love my chapters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gives her an "aren't you funny" look, opens door. Mel looks back at Coraline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did not call him crazy, Coraline.   He's drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes the hand-thumb bottle sign. Charlie leans in to Coraline, pinches her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I'll see you around, you dizzy dreamer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline cuts him off, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Da-ad! I'm not five anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad sighs, heads up the steps to his appointment as Mel and Coraline drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRESIDENT'S DAY SALE. Mel piles gray blouses, a navy skirt, white socks onto the arms of a CLERK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting alone on some stairs, Coraline sees a pair of fancy GREEN AND ORANGE GLOVES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she tries them on, a YOUNG RASCAL in costume with sword BOUNCES PAST her down the stairs on a WHEELED STEP STOOL - his FATHER in pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My kingdom for a hooooooorse!!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an off screen crash, then the step stool rolls back to Coraline. She gets an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mel is checking out school blouses, when Coraline rolls past, first one direction, then the other, modeling the colorful gloves. Without looking up, her mom tells her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put them back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Mom, the whole school's gonna wear boring gray clothes. No one will have these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put them back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline mutters:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My other mother would get them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she should buy all your clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline scowls and stomps away to return the gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline and Mel are driving home, shopping bags in back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you think's in the other apartment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Not a family of Jones imposters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why'd you lock the door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shorter than previous) Oh, I found some rat crap and... I thought you'd feel ... safer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're jumping-mice, Mom! And the dreams aren't dangerous; they're the most fun I've had since we've moved here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your school might be fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With those stupid uniforms?   Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had to give it a try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull into their DRIVEWAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mel pulls out salsa, mustard, catsup, stale tortillas from the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you feel about a mustard-ketchup- salsa wrap for lunch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline, carrying in the bags from outside, makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm... Had to go food shopping anyway. Dad's planning something special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline squinches up her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gross-gusting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna come along? You can pick out something you like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline plops down in a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, like the gloves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mel reaches out and musses Coraline's hair. The girl pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Coraline... if things go well today, I promise I'll make it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you always say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom rolls her eyes, shaking her head, and opens the door to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't be long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I might be...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline pulls open the key drawer, looking for the small black key. Not there. She looks around, then spots it hanging on a hook above a door. She stands on a chair and snags it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline stoops in front of the small door and pushes the key into the keyhole and unlocks the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She listens for her mother's car. Nothing. Grasping the key between thumb and forefinger, she closes her eyes, she pulls the door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON CORALINE: A SOFT BREEZE MOVES her hair. She knows before her eyes open that the BRICKS ARE GONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it was real!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens her eyes, smiles, and CRAWLS FORWARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON CORALINE THROUGH WINDOW. CAMERA PULLS BACK and we FIND the BLACK CAT, perched on the wet window sill, OBSERVING Coraline as she disappears into the tunnel. With a look of concern, he exits frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunch is ready and waiting for her: foot-long hotdogs with relish; grilled cheese sandwiches with gherkins; curly-fries; piles of coleslaw and potato salad; five flavors of soda-pop. There's a NOTE attached to a GIFT-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dearest Coraline, M iss Spink and Miss Forcible have invited you downstairs after lunch. I hope you like the new outfit I made you! Love, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline tears open the box and finds a pair of beautiful BLUE BOOTS, BLACK CORDUROY TROUSERS, and a METALLIC GREY SWEATER WITH TWINKLING STARS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds up the sweater to her body, smiles, then puts down the clothes and digs into lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline, dressed in her FANCY NEW CLOTHES, steps onto the FRONT PORCH and BURPS. It's always nighttime in this world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CAT MEEEROWS. Coraline looks up to see a BLACK CAT on the porch roof above her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline raises her brows, studies the animal a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm... Wybie's got a cat like you at home. Not the quiet Wybie; the one that talks too much. You must be the Other Cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat LEAPS down and lands on the railing by the basement stairs. He shakes his head and SPEAKS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm not the other anything. I'm me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tips his head to one side, opal blue eyes glinting. Coraline is surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... I can see you don't have button eyes. But if you're the same cat, how can you talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat shrugs from the tip of his tail to his whiskers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaps smoothly from the railing and onto a large, FALLEN TREE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cats don't talk at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Climbs up the tree's upended roots, head held high and proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're clearly the expert on these things. After all, I'm just a big fat wuss puss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come back. Please? I... I'm sorry I called you that, I really am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coraline forces herself to be polite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you get here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been coming here for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He DISAPPEARS behind one a thick root that sticks up, then REAPPEARS from a large knot hole beside Coraline, startling her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a game we play. She... (indicates house) ...hates cats and tries to keep me out. But she can't, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pokes his HEAD DOWN into the knot hole, then POPS IT UP out of ANOTHER KNOT-HOLE, ten feet away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I come and go as I please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
